Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Tsunami and Tropical Cyclone Sediment Dynamics and Products
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tsunamis and tropical cyclones pose a serious hazard to coastal communities. Quantifying this hazard is challenging in part because instrumental and historical datasets are too short to capture the extreme range of flood conditions possible at any particular location. Deposits from tsunamis and tropical cyclones, preserved within coastal sediments, provide a means to extend these records. However, there is significant uncertainty related to the movement of sediment during tsunamis and tropical cyclones, which hinders the interpretation of these event deposits.

To gain insight in sediment transport during tsunamis and tropical cyclones, computational modeling, informed by the properties of modern and paleo sedimentary deposits, will be performed. One assumption is that similarities exist in flow and transport processes between tsunamis and tropical cyclones; therefore, much can be learned from studying the two phenomena in tandem. Another assumption is that natural patterns exist in tsunami and tropical cyclone deposits such that correlations between deposit properties and their causative event can be obtained with advanced statistical methods coupled to computational modeling. The study will advance understanding of sediment transport during tsunamis and tropical cyclones and will improve the capability to predict the impact of future tsunami and tropical cyclones with more certainty, resulting in more resilient coastal planning, potentially saving lives and protecting livelihoods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this study were to: 1. provide an advanced understanding on the first principles of erosion, transport and deposition during extreme coastal inundation, 2. improve models of these extreme events and their impacts on natural systems, and 3) develop methods for the delineation of tsunami and storm events within the sedimentary record. 

Intellectual Merit: Towards Goal 1, Baranes et al. (2016) developed a new inverse sediment transport model and applied it to event deposits collected along the Pacific facing coast of southern Japan in order to provide the first physically-based height constraint for tsunamis derived from the Nankai Trough.  To advance our understanding on extreme flooding further we expanded our research in Baranes et al. (2018) by integrating novel earthquake modeling techniques and numerical simulations of tsunami generation, propagation, and inundation (Goal 2). The results of Baranes et al. (2018) now provide a new methodology for constructing earthquake rupture scenarios based on scaling interseismic coupling (frictional locking along a fault interface estimated by GPS) to coseismic slip. Our early Japan research opened new opportunities in assessing typhoon versus tsunami risk in southwestern Japan that was expanded upon by Ladlow et al. (2019) and Cho et al., (in review). In Ladlow et al. (2019) we develop and apply a new sediment fingerprinting technique to deconvolve deposition derived from extreme storm induced precipitation and marine associated flooding (Goal 3). This work was further expanded upon by Cho et al., (in review) where we present detailed counts of diatomic assemblages in order to improve upon our understanding of tsunami and typhoon inundation and resultant geomorphic and environmental change (Goal 2 and Goal 3). In tandem to our Japan studies, PI Woodruff worked closely with collaborators to assess and improve upon inverse modeling techniques for assessing storm derived flood intensity based on resulting flood deposits within salt marsh complexes (Castagno et al., 2020a), (Goal 1 and 2). Results from a more recent field campaign to Puerto Rico following Hurricane Maria are forthcoming with the intent of providing contributions to Goals 1-3. Results from all this work were incorporated into two peer-reviewed book chapters designed to provide the state of knowledge for those working in the principal disciplines of geomorphology and sedimentology with interests on sediment transport and deposition via inundation my tsunamis and storms (Wallace & Woodruff, 2020; Castagno et al., 2020b), (Goal 1-3).

Broader Impacts: The risk of impacts to Japan by a tsunami derived from the Nankai Trough are of great concern for the country. For example, Japan’s Headquarters for Earthquake Research Promotion estimates that there is a 60-70% chance of a magnitude 8–9 earthquake occurring within the next few decades. Our results from Japan have had a direct impact on improving hazard assessments for the country and has helped to describe how regional faulting has behaved during similar rupture scenarios in the past. In turn, our results have broad reaching impacts to the wide array of disciplines concerned with flood hazards for the country.  Results extend globally to any region that is vulnerable to earthquakes and where constructing rupture scenarios based on scientific observations of faults is key to managing risk. Further, record breaking floods in Kyushu in 2018 and 2020 highlight extreme precipitation as an additional flood hazards for the country. Our work delineating the impacts of extreme rainfall from marine inundation for typhoons highlights this additional flood and helps identify methods for delineating storm vs. tsunamis induced flooding for different regions in Japan (as well as Puerto Rico), while also helping to place both of these hazards in context and evaluate the relative risk.

Student Engagement: The project has supported the dissertation work of 4 UMass graduates students (3 female and 1 diversity fellow). Addition support provided to PI Woodruff allowed for his guidance and input to thesis content and the publications of two additional graduate students external to UMass. Products by these UMass and non-UMass students include 5 student authored publications (Baranes et al., 2016; Baranes et al., 2018; Ladlow et al., 2019; Castagno et al., 2020a and Cho et al., in review), and 8 first-authored student presentations at national meetings (e.g. AGU, GSA and the Japanese Geoscience Union). A UMass senior undergraduate thesis and UMass Sedimentology Honors Colloquium were also framed around laboratory analyses of sediments collected from Japan as part of the project, and the more recent Puerto Rico field work involved participation and training of two additional UMass M.S. graduate students.  

Note: Virginia Tech as lead institution has received an additional no-cost extension until 7/31/2021. As such, the outcome material provided above is focused to UMass activities as the non-lead collaborative institution. A more complete description of products and outcomes that include those from Virginia Tech will be provided by them following the formal completion of their project in 2021.
